Participants.evidence: Participants were selected based on the proximity of their tumors or epileptic foci to the motor cortex.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved mapping the motor network using intrinsic activity correlations, while the comparator was task-elicited activation of the motor system.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the feasibility of using low-frequency components of spontaneous functional MR imaging signals for presurgical motor function mapping in patients with tumors or epileptic foci near the motor cortex.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the precision of motor function mapping, assessed by comparing intrinsic activity correlations with task-elicited activation and direct cortical stimulation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization and allocation concealment methods were not applicable.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The motor regions identified through intrinsic activity correlations were similar to those defined by task-elicited activation and cortical stimulation.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was not registered as a randomized controlled trial.
